bestBHT.bht: By faith, believers have the ability to subdue kingdoms, just like David and Gideon. They can carry out righteous acts, mirroring Samuel and David. Through faith, the mouths of lions are stopped - a testament to unwavering belief in God, exemplified in the stories of Samson, David, and Benaiah. The author employs a sledge-hammer style, presenting nine profound acts accomplished by faith. This encourages believers to fearlessly face earthly powers, secure in the knowledge that faith allows them to obtain and patiently await the fulfillment of God's promises.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: subdued kingdoms—as David did... so also Gideon subdued Midian.
wrought righteousness—as Samuel did... and David.
stopped the mouths of lions—Note the words, 'because he believed in his God.' Also Samson, David, Benaiah.
Albert Barnes: Carried the laws of justice into execution
Philip Schaff: Through faith...the expression for the last time in this chapter, and specially appropriate as describing the instrument by which those great works were accomplished."
Obtained promises, i.e obtained the fulfilment of them, not indeed of the great promise of all, but of the lesser promises which God fulfilled to the prophets themselves.
Stopped the mouths of lions...specially of Daniel, of whom it is said that an angel shut the mouths of the lions, because he believed in his God.
Archibald T. Robertson: Through faith...first aorist middle indicative of καταγωνιζομα, Koine verb to struggle against, to overcome, here alone in the N.T. Used by Josephus of David's conquests.
The author has here (verses Hebrews 11:33; Hebrews 11:34), 'nine terse clauses' (Moffatt) with no connective (asyndeton) with great rhetorical and oratorical force (sledge-hammer style).
Stopped the mouths of lions...first aorist active indicative of φρασσω, old verb to fence in, to block up.
John Gill: Believers have no reason to be afraid of kings, or kingdoms; and this should encourage the saints, in their combats with the powers of darkness.
It may be observed, that to do works of righteousness in faith, and by it, is something very considerable; it is reckoned here among actions of the greatest fame.
Their faith was not the cause of promises being made, nor of their being fulfilled; but was the grace by which these believers received them, believed them, and waited for the accomplishment of them.

bhtAttempts.bht: Faith has the power to subdue kingdoms, just as David and Gideon did. It empowers believers to carry out acts of righteousness, just as Samuel and David did. Through faith, believers can stop the mouths of lions, as we see in the examples of Samson, David, and Benaiah. The author of Hebrews uses a sledge-hammer style to highlight the nine powerful acts accomplished through faith. This includes stopping the mouths of lions, which can be seen in the story of Daniel and how an angel shut the mouths of the lions because of his unwavering belief in God. This passage encourages believers to fearlessly face earthly powers and rely on faith to obtain God's promises and patiently wait for their fulfillment.

By faith, believers have the ability to subdue kingdoms, just like David and Gideon. They can carry out righteous acts, mirroring Samuel and David. Through faith, the mouths of lions are stopped - a testament to unwavering belief in God, exemplified in the stories of Samson, David, and Benaiah. The author employs a sledge-hammer style, presenting nine profound acts accomplished by faith. This encourages believers to fearlessly face earthly powers, secure in the knowledge that faith allows them to obtain and patiently await the fulfillment of God's promises.

Through faith, believers can subdue kingdoms, carry out acts of righteousness, and even stop the mouths of lions. This sledge-hammer style passage highlights these powerful acts accomplished by faith. Drawing from the examples of David, Gideon, Samuel, Samson, and Benaiah, it teaches believers to fearlessly face earthly powers and rely on faith to obtain and patiently await the fulfillment of God's promises. Faith empowers believers to overcome any obstacle, displaying the remarkable power and unwavering trust in God.

Through faith, believers have the power to subdue kingdoms, wrought righteousness, and stop the mouths of lions. The author uses a sledge-hammer style, presenting nine terse clauses that highlight these faith-driven accomplishments. Drawing from the examples of David, Gideon, Samuel, Samson, and Benaiah, this passage encourages believers to fearlessly face earthly powers, relying on their unwavering belief in God. By having faith, believers can obtain and patiently await the fulfillment of God's promises, knowing that their actions are governed by the remarkable power of faith.

Faith empowers believers to subdue kingdoms, carry out righteousness, and stop the mouths of lions. The sledge-hammer style of this verse showcases the remarkable acts accomplished through faith. Drawing inspiration from David, Gideon, Samuel, Samson, and Benaiah, it encourages believers to fearlessly confront earthly powers, relying on their unwavering trust in God. By having faith, believers can obtain and patiently await the fulfillment of God's promises, as their actions are guided by the extraordinary power of faith.
